Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Philip Garner of the Department of Chemistry at Washington State University to explore the development of a new chemical strategy (aziridine mediated peptide ligation) for the union of unprotected peptide segments and modification of the resulting product at the ligation site. This two-stage process begins with the chemoselective Cu(II)-promoted coupling of an unprotected peptide thioacid and unprotected aziridinyl peptide under native conditions to give an initial product with a reactive aziridine ring embedded at a pre-determined site. The coupling reaction is followed by an aziridine ring-opening reaction to give the final ligation product. This project will address two important chemical ligation problems that remain to be solved: (1) the need to develop more general peptide ligation methodology that circumvents the N-terminal Cys requirement of native chemical ligation and (2) the need for chemical ligation methodology that enables the site-specific introduction of modifications during the ligation event.

The technology resulting from this project could impact the fields of Biology, Medicine, and Nanotechnology. The educational component of this project will include training graduate students and undergraduate researchers, so as to prepare them for either academic or industrial careers in chemistry. An effort will be made to recruit students from underrepresented groups to work on this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project resulted in the development of synthetic methodology for the site-specific modification of peptides. Two new chemical ligation reactions were discovered, one involving peptide ligation with the concurrent incorporation of an aziridine ring as well as a glycoligation reaction that enables the site-specific attachment of a carbohydrate to a full-length peptide chain. In the former case, the aziridine provides a reactive handle for site-specific modification of the peptide. The ligations proceed rapidly under mild reaction conditions and are tolerent of water. Both of these reactions can be performed on unprotected peptides, obviating the reliance on traditional protecting group strategies to enforce chemoselectivity. These attributes not only makes the reactions environmentally friendly but also suggest their possible future use for the site-specific modification of proteins, an active area of research. Post-translational protein modifications play important roles in a variety of biological processes. The chemical technology resulting from this project could enable future research to elucidate the biological roles of specific protein modifications. 

Broader Impacts: The project advanced the STEM education of students, including disadvantaged minorities, who either have already entered or will enter the United States workforce. Graduate students and undergraduate students conducted cutting edge research that resulted in their acquisition of the skillset needed to perform organic synthesis. Opportunities for teaching/training and mentoring arose from the interaction of more senior members of the project team with their junior colleagues. These activities served to prepare students for graduate studies (undergraduate researchers) and careers in industry and academia (graduate students).
